The mass media* as Lazarsfeld and Merton pointed out ten years ago*
are integrated into the business organization of the country* And they shel-
ter themselves and business organizations generally from criticism through
(1) the narcotic effect of their product, and (2) excluding or softening

criticism of the social system**^ The nurturing of the folklore described by
Arnold is part of these two aspects of mass media operation© Whether all of
this is the result of intention or is a by-product of other purposes is
indeterminate and indeed irrelevant; the effect is present in either case*
The end result is to centralize enormous power in the business community while
for the individual enforcing an emphasis on present spending and present
enjoyment.
In this context, the social distance between the individual and the
decision-making which controls his destiny is increasedo The spread of the
market into the area of cultural goods and services(as distinct from producers*
goods) has alienated the individual and primary group from self-sufficiencyo
The individual tends to be isolated in cultural matters* This is the counter¬
part to the alienation from ownership and control of the tools of production
accompanying the earlier Industrial Revolution, which was so conspicuous a
